name: Plastic Water Bottles
description: Plastic bottles can leach chemicals like BPA and antimony into water, especially when exposed to heat. These chemicals are potential endocrine disruptors.
recommendation: Opt for reusable glass or stainless steel bottles. If using plastic, avoid leaving them in hot cars and recycle them after a single use.

name: Non-stick Cookware
description: When overheated, non-stick coatings (like Teflon) can release perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA), a chemical linked to various health issues.
recommendation: Use cast iron, stainless steel, or ceramic cookware. If using non-stick, cook on low to medium heat and avoid using metal utensils.

name: Artificial Sweeteners
description: Some studies suggest that long-term consumption of artificial sweeteners could alter gut bacteria and may be associated with metabolic issues.
recommendation: Reduce overall sugar intake. Use natural sweeteners like stevia or monk fruit in moderation.

name: Air Fresheners
description: Many air fresheners contain volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and phthalates, which can trigger allergies and asthma and may be endocrine disruptors.
recommendation: Use natural alternatives like essential oil diffusers, opening windows for ventilation, or simmering spices on the stove.

name: Processed Meats
description: The World Health Organization has classified processed meats as a Group 1 carcinogen, linked to an increased risk of colorectal cancer.
recommendation: Limit consumption of processed meats like bacon, sausage, and hot dogs. Choose fresh, unprocessed cuts of meat whenever possible.

name: Canned Foods
description: Some cans are lined with a resin containing BPA. While the risk is generally low, it's a known endocrine disruptor. Acidic foods can increase leaching.
recommendation: Look for cans labeled "BPA-free." Whenever possible, choose fresh or frozen foods over canned versions.
